faq.title: FAQ — Quality Tools in Manufacturing
faq.a1: A Check Sheet is a structured QC table used to collect frequency of defect occurrences directly from manufacturing processes.
faq.a2: A Pareto Diagram is a QC chart used to identify vital defect causes that contribute to 80% of quality problems.
faq.a3: In industrial quality, a Histogram is used to visualize distribution of measurement data such as dimension, thickness, or tolerance deviation.
faq.q4: How do I upload data from Excel?
faq.a4: Click 'Upload Excel' and select a sheet containing columns for categories and counts.
faq.a5: No. Your QC data never leaves your browser. Nothing is uploaded.
faq.q6: Is this tool free for industry use?
faq.a6: Yes. The platform is 100% free for engineering, industry, students, and research purposes.
faq.q7: Is this tool usable on factory floor tablets?
faq.a7: Yes. QC Tools is responsive and can be used on mobile or industrial touchscreen terminals.

checksheet_theory.title: CHECK SHEET — Summary of Theory & Application Implementation
checksheet_theory.section1_id: A check sheet is a structured form used to collect quality data directly from the production process. Its purpose is to ensure accuracy, readability, and analysis readiness.
checksheet_theory.section1_en: A check sheet is a structured tool for recording quality data directly at the production site for reliable analysis.
checksheet_theory.section1_intro: According to quality literature, check sheets are used to:
checksheet_theory.section1_point4: Prepare data for statistical analysis such as Pareto, stratification, and histograms.
checksheet_theory.section1_close: This application implements all these functions through four check sheet modules.
checksheet_theory.section2_title: 2. Four Check Sheet Types in the Application
checksheet_theory.A_id: Used to record the number of defects by category over time.
checksheet_theory.A_en: Used to track defect counts per category by day or shift.
checksheet_theory.A_theory: This check sheet is used to count defect types, identify dominant defects, and observe frequency patterns.
checksheet_theory.A_imp4: Pareto analysis to determine priority defects.
checksheet_theory.B_id: Maps defect locations on a product using a circular–radial matrix.
checksheet_theory.B_en: Used to record defect positions on products using a structured grid.
checksheet_theory.B_theory: Location check sheets help identify areas where defects occur most frequently.
checksheet_theory.B_imp2: Location input with severity and comments.
checksheet_theory.C_id: Maps defects across workers, days, shifts, and defect types.
checksheet_theory.C_en: Used to identify causes by linking worker–day–shift–defect patterns.
checksheet_theory.C_theory: This sheet helps determine who, when, and under what conditions defects occur.
checksheet_theory.C_imp3: Identification of problematic workers and shifts.
checksheet_theory.D_id: Records variation of process characteristics relative to target, LSL, and USL.
checksheet_theory.D_en: Used to track process measurements in comparison to specification limits.
checksheet_theory.D_theory: Deviation-based check sheets support histogram preparation and variation analysis.
checksheet_theory.D_imp1: Automatic deviation and actual value calculation.
checksheet_theory.section3_title: 3. Theoretical Principles Applied in the Application
checksheet_theory.section3_p1_text: Each check sheet has a specific purpose: defects, location, causes, or variation.
checksheet_theory.section3_p2_text: Data is recorded in structured formats based on QC literature.
checksheet_theory.section3_p3_text: The application ensures simple, consistent input with data-locking features.
checksheet_theory.section3_p4_text: Data can be used directly for Pareto, pattern analysis, or stratification.
checksheet_theory.section4_point1: Digital and interactive for fast input.
checksheet_theory.section4_point4: Export to PDF, Excel, CSV, or share link.
checksheet_theory.section5_text: The four check sheet modules in this application adapt classical QC theory into a complete, accurate, and easy-to-use digital format.

pareto_theory.title: Teori Pareto dan Klasifikasi ABC
pareto_theory.section1_desc1: Prinsip Pareto menyatakan bahwa sebagian kecil penyebab bertanggung jawab atas sebagian besar dampak. Dalam analisis kualitas, konsep ini digunakan untuk mengidentifikasi kategori defect yang paling berpengaruh.
pareto_theory.section1_desc2: Pareto Chart mengurutkan kategori berdasarkan jumlah defect terbesar dan menampilkan persentase kumulatif untuk menentukan prioritas perbaikan.
pareto_theory.section1_point1: Sebagian kecil kategori menghasilkan sebagian besar total defect.
pareto_theory.section1_point2: Urutan kategori membantu fokus pada masalah terbesar terlebih dahulu.
pareto_theory.section1_point3: Line chart cumulative percentage digunakan untuk menentukan batas prioritas 80%.
pareto_theory.section1_point4: Area sampai 80% dianggap sebagai zona prioritas perbaikan.
pareto_theory.section2_desc: Klasifikasi ABC adalah metode untuk mengelompokkan kategori berdasarkan kontribusinya terhadap total defect menggunakan cumulative percentage.
pareto_theory.A_desc: Kategori dengan kontribusi hingga sekitar 70–80% dari total. Jumlah kategori sedikit namun dampaknya besar. Menjadi prioritas perbaikan utama.
pareto_theory.B_desc: Kategori dengan kontribusi di rentang 80–90%. Perlu perhatian tetapi tidak sepenting kategori A.
pareto_theory.C_desc: Kategori dengan kontribusi terakhir sekitar 10–20%. Dampaknya kecil dan biasanya banyak. Perbaikan hanya jika biaya rendah atau bersifat housekeeping.
pareto_theory.section3_point2: Mengalokasikan sumber daya secara lebih efektif.
pareto_theory.section3_point3: Menyaring masalah menjadi tiga tingkat urgensi.
pareto_theory.section4_text: Analisis Pareto dan klasifikasi ABC memberikan struktur prioritas yang jelas untuk tindakan perbaikan. Keduanya memastikan bahwa upaya pengendalian kualitas difokuskan pada area dengan dampak terbesar.

histogram_theory.title: Histogram Theory and Distributions
histogram_theory.s1_desc1: If all factors in a process were perfectly constant, all data would take the same value. In reality, it is impossible to keep all conditions fixed.
histogram_theory.s1_desc2: Data values change continuously but follow certain patterns. These patterns are called distributions.
histogram_theory.s1_desc3: Understanding distributions allows us to see how data is spread and how the process behaves.
histogram_theory.s2_desc1: In quality control, samples are collected to evaluate the condition of the population.
histogram_theory.s2_desc2: A sample is used for decision-making in process control or lot inspection.
histogram_theory.s2_point1: The population is the entire set of possible data.
histogram_theory.s2_point2: A sample is a subset taken from the population.
histogram_theory.s2_point3: Random sampling is used to obtain good representation.
histogram_theory.s3_desc1: A histogram is a visual tool for understanding data distribution using class intervals (bins).
histogram_theory.s3_desc2: As dataset size increases, tables become harder to interpret—histograms help reveal patterns more clearly.
histogram_theory.s4_desc: The shape of a histogram provides clues about the state of a process. These are common types:
histogram_theory.type_general_desc: The highest frequency appears at the center and gradually decreases toward both ends.
histogram_theory.type_general_note: This is the most common and stable shape.
histogram_theory.type_comb_note: Often occurs when multiple distributions are mixed or class intervals are inadequate.
histogram_theory.type_positive_desc: A peak on the left with a long tail extending to the right.
histogram_theory.type_positive_note: Occurs when the upper limit is loosely controlled.
histogram_theory.type_left_precipice_desc: A peak very close to the left boundary with a steep drop to the right.
histogram_theory.type_left_precipice_note: Occurs when the lower limit is tightly controlled.
histogram_theory.type_plateau_desc: Relatively flat frequencies across the middle region.
histogram_theory.type_plateau_note: Indicates the presence of several merged subpopulations.
histogram_theory.type_twin_peak_note: Occurs when two distinct processes are combined.
histogram_theory.type_isolated_desc: A small, separate peak appears in addition to the main distribution.
histogram_theory.type_isolated_note: May indicate measurement error, abnormal data, or mixing from another process.
histogram_theory.s5_desc1: When specification limits exist, the histogram can be compared with them to evaluate the process condition.
histogram_theory.s5_ok1: Histogram is fully within the specification limits.
histogram_theory.s5_ok2: The mean is located at the center of the specification.
histogram_theory.s5_ok3: Variation is small enough to satisfy the requirement.
histogram_theory.s5_bad1: The mean is shifted away from the center.
histogram_theory.s5_bad2: Variation is too large relative to the specification width.
histogram_theory.s6_desc1: Stratification is used when data originate from several different conditions.
histogram_theory.s6_desc2: Each group is treated as a separate subpopulation called a stratum.
histogram_theory.s7_desc1: Histograms help compute fundamental statistical properties.
histogram_theory.s7_mean: Mean: the central location of the distribution.
histogram_theory.s7_variance: Variance: the degree of spread among the data.
histogram_theory.s7_stddev: Standard deviation: the square root of variance.
histogram_theory.s8_desc1: A normal distribution emerges when the number of data becomes sufficiently large and influences are independent.
histogram_theory.s8_point2: The central frequency is the highest.
histogram_theory.s8_desc2: A normal distribution is characterized by two parameters: the mean (μ) and the standard deviation (σ).
histogram_theory.s9_desc1: Used to determine whether a process can satisfy specification limits.
histogram_theory.s9_cp: Cp measures the width of the process relative to tolerance.
histogram_theory.s9_cpk: Cpk measures how centered the process mean is within the specification.
